column4: i have lost my user password, and try to boot the computer into recovery mode (from grub) to be able to set it again, but ends up in "give root password" (which I don't have) or Ctrl-D which leads back to normal KDM log in. How can I come to a prompt where I can set my user password?
did you set a root password? iirc you should not be prompted unless you actually gave the root user a password
you might be able to bypass it by adding init=/bin/bash as a kernel boot parameter
where do I add that?
in the grub screen hit e and then add it before the -- in the kernel line
no -- in the kernel line, just kernel /boot/vmlinuz-xxxxxxx root=......
that's fine
so where do I put it....?
before kernel?
anywhere on the line
hrm...addning that makes the boot hang at a usb-device
it is sort of an old trick, i am not too surprised that it doesn't work on these new fangled systems
if you can you should just use a live cd
yes, how do I use that to change pw?
once you get into a live cd, chroot into the old environment and run passwd
i got the live CD running now, am I to do chroot <root of my hard disk file system> then?
if you have the old system mounted at say /mnt/ubuntu , you would run sudo chroot /mnt/ubuntu
then you're basically in the old system and you can reset your password with passwd
feel a bit stupid - my old system does not seem to be mounted - is there a way to find out where it is, or do I just guess at /dev/hda?
oh, you need to mount it first, e.g. 'mkdir /mnt/ubuntu && mount /dev/hda1 /mnt/ubuntu'
ok, now I have the root file system identified - but not the home directories (on another partition) - do I need those as well?
no, you just need /etc to change the passwords
great, now it works, thanks a lot!!!
